instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with a intermittent fault.

It always turns on with a charged battery but doesn't always charge the battery.
When it doesn't charge, theres no green or orange light.
When it does charge, it shows orange light as normal.

I've noticed that if its in a charging kind of mood, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.42-12.5v
If the charger is removed when its 12.5v, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> instantly drops to 12.02v and sometimes drops to 11.4v ish

If the charger is plugged back in and PPBUS is above 12v on the battery, PPBUS jumps to 12.5v then drops back to late 11v or early 12v and slowly climbs up to 12.5v

If the charger is plugged back in and PPBUS is low.. like 11.4 or something, it won't light the magsafe but will eventually creep up PPBU to the 12v+ mark and start charging etc

I was thinking SMC issue or <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> after reading previous posts but want other opinions before I remove anything.

Second battery tried is known good but doesn't change the behaviour.
Charger is my 85w original


Running off the battery only, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.04 in S5.. then when I power on the MacBook. It actually turns on fine but PPBUS drops to 11.4-11.6v instantly. If i then plug in the charger, it won't charge or light up the magsafe until one of two things happen.. either <SIGNAL>PPBU_G3H</SIGNAL> creeps up to 11.84-11.85v and then the charger comes on and it jumps to 12.5v or if it doesn't creep up, if I turn off the MacBook, it usually initiates the voltage creep up to 11.84v-11.85v at which point it jumps to 12.5 once it sees the 11.84v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message: The voltage drops because the battery is not fully charged which is normal. What is your exact voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with just the charger now battery? Check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message:
Try first another DCIN board.
Battery is not charging if no Magsafe light.

Look around <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01; check solders, traces...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message:
[USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] Exact voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with the battery removed, just 85w charger and the MacBook turned both off and on is 12.48v-12.49v

On <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>) resistance between 17/18 is 2.8 - between 27/28 is 20 ohms which both seem fine I think.


[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] I'm checking <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/<CHIP>U6901</CHIP> now for any issues and I'll try another DCIN to see if anything changes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message:
[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] Changing the DCIN didn't make any differences. Checked around <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 under the microscope and it all looks perfect unfortunately.

Just to be clear. When <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is below 11.84v (usually around 11-11.4v when just on battery) the magsafe light doesn't come on and the battery doesn't charge. But when <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 11.84v or above, the magsafe light does come on and the battery charges perfectly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message:
"Checked around <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01 under the microscope and it all looks perfect unfortunately."
I was expecting to get some voltages for <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>/01, when NO Magsafe light present...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage varies, according with battery charge level; you can have 6V there, with empty battery.
Be sure =<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> is always high; <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> should also be high.
If not, change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message:
Sorry, thought I was just looking for damaged traces, liquid etc..

<CHIP>U6901</CHIP> Pin 1/2 <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0v, Pin 3 GND = 0.0v, Pin 4 <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 0.0v, Pin 5 <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.452v

I'll check voltages on <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> now too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message: PPBUS is 12.48 with just the charger? This makes me think maybe there is corrosion under the SMC. Remove edge bonding and give it a light reflow. See if it comes all the way up to 12.6 after that

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not always charging battery
threads.message: Ultrasonic clean and an SMC reflow did the trick. Tested for a couple of days without the problem returning. Thank you for the help
